A reminder from our school nurses:

Even though our schools are currently in a period of online learning, immunizations are very important and are still required for all students by the State of Indiana.

A complete list of all required immunizations for school is available on our website at http://educateMC.net/immunizations.

Please note that there are newly required immunizations for kindergarten, 6th grade and 12th grade -- so it is especially important for parents at those grade levels to be sure students are up to date.

In addition, proof of lead testing is also required for all students in kindergarten.

Our school nurses also highly recommend that every student receive a flu vaccination this year.

Thank you for your help in ensuring that all students are up to date on immunizations and stay as healthy as possible this school year! If you have any questions or need additional information, please reach out to your child’s school nurse.

post_text: Lee Lonzo (Class of ’69 and son of longtime teacher Del Lonzo) sent these items to MCAS for display in Heritage Hall. From Lee: "In case you did not know my father’s story, he was at Elston until Rogers opened. He ran junior concessions at the Red Devil football and basketball games for many years. At basketball games he would take off his sport coat sometime in the 2nd half and reveal his bright red vest as a signal for the workers to leave the stands and quit for the night. This usually brought a huge response from the entire crowd." The net pieces were from each step towards the 1966 State Championship. "He would never tell me who gave him the net pieces since Coach Adams had threatened anyone who did that." Thank you for sharing these pieces of City history, Lee!

post_text: Another successful year for MCHS at the Japanese Olympiad! Congratulations to all! #onecityonepack #MCASGiantLeaps
shared_text:
Michigan City High School
February 24 at 6:15 PM ·

MORE good news! MCHS placed 2nd in two divisions at the Japanese Olympiad of Indiana on Saturday, which was held at Purdue. At level 3, the team of Erica Galindo, Mia Taylor, and Linda Will took 2nd in the state! The level 4 team of Robert Lemon, Parker Gouge, and Megan Steinhiser also took 2nd in the state!

City also fielded a pair of Level 2 teams that had strong showings in the preliminary round: kudos to Jonathan Creal, Owen Wilson, and Alyssa Walters, and to Brooklyn Fugate, Allison Wilson, and Orion Bennett.

During the competition, students learned about/took part in demos on various aspects of Japanese culture, including Shakuhachi (a traditional flute), a traditional tea ceremony, and a demonstration of Japanese swordsmanship (kendo) by the Purdue Kendo Club.

MCHS even had several fans in the audience at the competition -- alums who now attend Purdue!

Tsugawa Sensei is proud of all our competitors and finalists, and wants to encourage all Wolves, regardless of their sport or skill, to take pride in what they do.

post_text: CONGRATULATIONS to these two AMAZING MCAS teachers! Tess Pavloff, kindergarten teacher at Edgewood, and Mariah Pol, Social Studies teacher at Barker, have been selected to receive Lilly Endowment Teacher Creativity Fellowships this summer. This fellowship enables educators to pursue their dreams and passions, explore new areas of interest, and develop new and existing talents. Tess will be traveling across the U.S. to several National Parks, using the experience to build cross-curricular connections through language arts, math, science, and art. Mariah will be exploring Greece and Egypt, creating Virtual Reality curricula that allows her students to analyze world history holistically and appreciate the world’s diversity. #onecityonepack #MCASGiantLeaps https://lillyendowment.org/for-grantseekers/renewal-programs/teacher-creativity/
